    Combine and Reshape Data by Specified Columns

    combn_pair2.Rd

    Transforms a wide-format dataset into a nested data structure by combining specified columns and grouping by traits.

    combn_pair2(data, cols2bind, by, nest_type = "dt")

    Arguments

    data

    A data frame or data table containing the input data

    cols2bind

    A single column name or index to use for binding/grouping

    by

    A vector of column names or indices representing traits to be combined

    nest_type

    The type of nested data structure to return. Options are "dt" (data.table) or "df" (data frame). Defaults to "dt".

    Value

    A data.table with two columns:

    • trait: The trait identifier

    • data: A list column containing nested data structures

    Details

    The function performs the following operations:

    • Converts input to data.table format

    • Validates input columns

    • Reshapes data to long format using melt()

    • Casts data to wide format using dcast()

    • Creates a nested data structure grouped by traits

    Note

    • Supports both numeric indices and column names for cols2bind and by

    • Automatically detects and preserves ID columns

    • Allows flexible reshaping of data with different nesting options

    Examples

    # Sample data
data <- data.frame(
  breed = c("A", "B", "A", "B"), 
  sex = c("F", "F", "M", "M"), 
  trait1 = c(1.1, 2.1, 3.5, 4.6),
  trait2 = c(5.2, 6.6, 7.3, 8.6))
# Method 1: Using combn_pair2() with data.table
# Combine by breed, grouping traits
combn_pair2(data, cols2bind = "breed", by = c("trait1", "trait2"))
#> Key: <trait>
#>     trait              data
#>    <fctr>            <list>
#> 1: trait1 <data.table[2x3]>
#> 2: trait2 <data.table[2x3]>

# Return as data frame nested structure
combn_pair2(data, cols2bind = "breed", 
                           by = c("trait1", "trait2"), 
                           nest_type = "df")
#> Key: <trait>
#>     trait              data
#>    <fctr>            <list>
#> 1: trait1 <data.frame[2x3]>
#> 2: trait2 <data.frame[2x3]>
# Method 2: Using tidyr and dplyr for similar transformation
data |>
  tidyr::pivot_longer(cols = c("trait1", "trait2"), names_to = "name", values_to = "value") |>
  tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = "breed", values_from = "value") |>
  dplyr::group_nest(name)
#> # A tibble: 2 × 2
#>   name                 data
#>   <chr>  <list<tibble[,3]>>
#> 1 trait1            [2 × 3]
#> 2 trait2            [2 × 3]
